articles.headline: Breach Grows Between Biden and Israel’s Leaders Over Rafah Invasion
articles.snippet: Defiant Israelis have vowed to do “whatever is necessary” in the Gaza Strip despite the American president’s threat to withhold weapons.
articles.abstract: Defiant Israelis have vowed to do “whatever is necessary” in the Gaza Strip despite the American president’s threat to withhold weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli leaders declared on Thursday that they would not be deterred by President Biden’s threat to withhold more arms shipments if the military launched a major assault on densely populated areas of Rafah in southern Gaza.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Why Higher Fed Rates Are Not Totally Off the Table
articles.snippet: Fed officials still think their next move will be to cut rates, but they are not entirely ruling out the possibility that they might have to raise them.
articles.abstract: Fed officials still think their next move will be to cut rates, but they are not entirely ruling out the possibility that they might have to raise them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors do not expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again, and officials have made it clear that they see further increases as unlikely. But one important takeaway from recent Fed commentary is that unlikely and inconceivable are not the same thing.

articles.headline: A Failed Crop Rattled the Chocolate Industry. Then Speculators Came.
articles.snippet: After a production shortfall in West Africa, cocoa prices rose to $4,000 a metric ton from $2,500. Then they went nuts.
articles.abstract: After a production shortfall in West Africa, cocoa prices rose to $4,000 a metric ton from $2,500. Then they went nuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A failed crop, followed by a wave of financial speculation, put cocoa prices on a roller coaster this year, rattling an industry reliant on inexpensive crops and labor.

articles.headline: For Mormon Missionaries, Some ‘Big, Big Changes’
articles.snippet: The church has loosened its strict rules for those evangelizing. And many members of Gen-Z are loving it.
articles.abstract: The church has loosened its strict rules for those evangelizing. And many members of Gen-Z are loving it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andres Gonzalez, 19, stands on the balcony of his Los Angeles apartment, his hands in his suit pockets. It is his first week as a missionary, but today, instead of approaching people on the street, he is shooting a video that he will later post to social media.

articles.headline: A German Initiative to Keep Workers Employed by Retraining Them
articles.snippet: As the industrial landscape in Germany shifts, companies have formed an alliance aimed at offering the skills and certification that workers need to find new jobs.
articles.abstract: As the industrial landscape in Germany shifts, companies have formed an alliance aimed at offering the skills and certification that workers need to find new jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Emrullah Karaca began working at a factory in Gifhorn, Germany, where the auto parts supplier Continental builds components for hydraulic brakes, he was looking for a temporary job after finishing high school.

articles.headline: For Columbia and a Powerful Donor, Months of Talks and Millions at Risk
articles.snippet: Columbia University has faced enormous public pressure over protests. But emails and interviews also show some of the private demands on the Ivy League school.
articles.abstract: Columbia University has faced enormous public pressure over protests. But emails and interviews also show some of the private demands on the Ivy League school.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Jan. 19, Angelica Berrie sent an email to Nemat Shafik, the president of Columbia University. Ms. Berrie reported that the Russell Berrie Foundation, named for her late husband, had scheduled three grant payments to Columbia.

articles.headline: Russia Mounting New Border Assaults in North, Ukraine Says
articles.snippet: Armored columns tried to punch through at several points, the military said, raising pressure on already stretched Ukrainian forces.
articles.abstract: Armored columns tried to punch through at several points, the military said, raising pressure on already stretched Ukrainian forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukraine rushed reinforcements to its northern border on Friday after Russian forces attempted to break through Ukrainian lines along several sections, applying new pressure on forces already stretched thin along a 600-mile front.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Maria Varenikova and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Biden Is Not the First U.S. President to Cut Off Weapons to Israel
articles.snippet: Other presidents, including, Ronald Reagan, used the power of American arms to influence Israeli war policy. But the comparisons underscore how much the politics of Israel have changed over the years.
articles.abstract: Other presidents, including, Ronald Reagan, used the power of American arms to influence Israeli war policy. But the comparisons underscore how much the politics of Israel have changed over the years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president was livid. He had just been shown pictures of civilians killed by Israeli shelling, including a small baby with an arm blown off. He ordered aides to get the Israeli prime minister on the phone and then dressed him down sharply.
